J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> David Saff wrote:
> > Was your other piece of code going to be reused as heavily as JUnit is?
>
> Probably not. This was more about demonstrating a technique than
> anything else.
>
> > Does that make a difference?
>
> I don't think it does. Do you?

I think it does, but I'm still figuring it out.  Cleverness in design 
often comes from metaphor: what if we could think of A as a kind of B?  
What if we could think of a String as an iterable collection of lines?  
(Ruby)  What if we could think of a flat panel as a spinnable wheel?  
(iPod)  What if we could think of methods as test statements?  (JUnit)  
What if we could think of basic blocks as runnable objects?  
(Smalltalk)  By capitalizing on the similarity between something that 
looks complex and something that we think we understand, we gain leverage.

However, these metaphors are not without costs.  There are distinctions 
in the world, and the adaptations that must be made are not always 
intuitive.  If you look at all the Xunit descendants in the world, there 
are many different answers to simple questions: should one object be 
created for each method, or each class?  How can we identify _which_ 
methods are tests?  Does it make sense to pass parameters to these test 
methods?  All of these need answers to adapt the idea of "test" to the 
idea of "method".  New users need time to "get" the basic metaphor, and 
then additional time to learn, often by frsutrating trial and surprising 
error, all of the gotchas.

Pluggable Selector, using reflection, is such a metaphor.  So, whether 
the cost of this metaphor is worth it depends on the benefit each user 
gets, and how many uses that cost is to be amortized across.

I'm still figuring this out, and I'm interested in your ideas.  Thanks,

    David Saff
